bibl.title: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 8, 1929

div1.p: Russell writes that he knew Walter Reed and values his work. He informs her that the Rockefeller Foundation has pursued yellow fever eradication since 1918.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick F. Russell to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 8, 1929
div1.opener:

SCIENTIFIC DIRECTORS
____
RUFUS COLE, M.D., CHAIRMAN
EUGENE L. BISHOP, M.D.
LOUIS I. DUBLIN, Ph.D.
WADE H. FROST, M.D.
FREDERICK F. RUSSELL, M.D.
WILSON G. EMILLIE, M.D.
C.E.A. WINSLOW, Dr.F.M.
Dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
Your note of the second of July has just reached
me. I am very glad to know that you have received word
of the interest many of us feel in your welfare and happi-
ness. It has been a great pleasure to me to have had any
part in helping to bring about improved conditions.

Although I was never a pupil at the Army Medical
School, I nevertheless, frequently came into contact with
your husband, and always derived great satisfaction and
pleasure from my contacts with him. In addition, the
Foundation, and particularly the International Health Di-
vision to which I belong, has worked continuously toward
the suppression of yellow fever since 1918, and we are to-
day very actively engaged in that work. In our studies we
picked up the work where Walter Reed left it in Havana in
1901, and have continued to add important details to our
knowledge of the disease. It has always been a source of
satisfaction to me to find that his work has in every de-
tail stood the severe test of time. Nothing has happened
in all these years to change in any way the conclusions at

With best wishes for a pleasant summer, I am
